title: How to Deduct Medical Expenses on Taxes

steps.headline: Review the list of deductible medical expenses on the IRS website.
steps.description: Search for Publication 502. Read the detailed list of deductible and ineligible medical expenses for the current tax year. For instance, if you are self-employed, you may be able to deduct your health insurance premiums from your adjusted gross income (AGI). The deductible medical expenses list does change from year to year, so do not judge based on a previous years' IRS publication.

steps.headline: Keep your receipts from medical costs throughout the year.
steps.description: Create a file where you can put all your receipts for everything from health insurance premiums to transportation expenses to and from medical appointments. By making an effort to keep them throughout the year, you are more likely to have a complete list of verifiable expenses at the end. Even if you don't have enough medical expenses to deduct them from your federal income tax, your state may allow a deduction for medical expenses.

steps.headline: Keep a spreadsheet of all your medical expenses.
steps.description: Include columns for the date, service, service provider, doctor prescribing the service and notes. Update your medical expenses based on your receipts monthly, or after each expense. Set your spreadsheet to keep a running tab of your medical expenses. On both Microsoft Excel and open source spreadsheet programs, you can select the column that you want to be added and click the "Formula" button. Select the cells you would like it to add, and there should be a total that changes as you add more entries into the "Cost" column.

steps.headline: Keep track of family members' medical expenses.
steps.description: Your medical expenses should include everyone who is included in your tax return, such as a spouse or children. However, it can also include other family members' expenses that you pay for, as long as it is not claimed on their own tax returns. You should also collect original receipts for family medical expenses.

steps.headline: Remove any medical expenses that were reimbursed.
steps.description: If any of your expenses were reimbursed by a doctor, an agency, an insurance company, or from a Health Savings Account (HSA), you cannot deduct them. It is illegal and fraudulent to deduct any medical expenses for which the financial burden did not fall on you.

steps.headline: Calculate your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) at year's end.
steps.description: AGI is calculated by subtracting a short list of expenses from all of the income you received from various sources during the year. Gather your W-2s and other forms for you and your spouse that show what income you received in the last year. Gross income includes the following income you may have received in the current financial year: wages or salary, bonuses, rents, royalty, alimony, interest, dividends, pensions, income from a business operation, annuities, and income tax refunds. Adjustments to gross income include the following payments made during the current financial year: business expenses, alimony paid, Health Savings Account contributions, one half of self-employment tax, contributions to traditional IRA retirement accounts, and college tuition.

steps.headline: Total your deductible medical expenses from the current tax year.
steps.description: You should be able to take the total of your spreadsheet at the end of the year. Add medical expenses from each family member together.

steps.headline: Multiply your AGI by 7.5% (0.075) for 2018 or 10% (0.10) for 2019.
steps.description: However, if this number is less than your total medical expenses, subtract this number from your medical expenses. The result will be the total amount you can deduct for medical expenses. If this number is more than your total medical expenses, you cannot deduct your medical expenses. For example, if your AGI was $50,000 and you spent $6,940 on deductible medical expenses in 2018, then you could itemize a deduction for medical expenses. This is because 7.5% of $50,000 is $3,750, less than what you spent on medical costs. Your total deduction would be $6,940 minus $3,750, or $3,190.

steps.headline: Request a Schedule A from the IRS, or print a copy online at IRS.gov.
steps.description: The standard deduction for 2018 for single filers is $12,000 or $24,000 for married filing jointly. If you choose to itemize your deductions because they are greater than the standard deduction, you will need to file a Schedule A. This is also called IRS Form 1040.

steps.headline: Fill in the top of the Form 1040, which says "Medical and Dental Expenses."
steps.description: Enter your deductible medical expenses in blank number 1 and your AGI in blank number 2. Enter 7.5% of your AGI for 2018 or 10% of your AGI for 2019 in blank number 3 and that amount subtracted from your medical expenses in blank number 4. If your medical expense total is lower than 7.5% (2018) or 10% (2019) of your AGI, you will enter "0" in blank number 4.

steps.headline: Complete your taxes and send them in before the due date in April.
steps.description: You can submit your taxes by mail, through a tax preparer or by using the e-file process. Although you do not need to send in your medical receipts, you should keep them and your spreadsheet in case of an audit.

It is illegal and fraudulent to deduct any medical expenses for which the financial burden did not fall on you. Determining Your Deductions Calculate your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) at year's end. AGI is calculated by subtracting a short list of expenses from all of the income you received from various sources during the year. If this number is more than your total medical expenses, you cannot deduct your medical expenses. If you choose to itemize your deductions because they are greater than the standard deduction, you will need to file a Schedule A. This is also called IRS Form 1040. Fill in the top of the Form 1040, which says "Medical and Dental Expenses." Enter your deductible medical expenses in blank number 1 and your AGI in blank number 2. Enter 7.5% of your AGI for 2018 or 10% of your AGI for 2019 in blank number 3 and that amount subtracted from your medical expenses in blank number 4.
